ZOO 101.question: The skeleton is the bony __________ of the body.
ZOO 101.explanation: The skeleton is the bony framework of the body.
ZOO 101.hint: Think of the basic structural role.

ZOO 101.question: The skeleton provides __________, shape, rigidity, and __________ to the soft tissues and organs.
ZOO 101.explanation: The skeleton provides support, shape, rigidity, and protection.
ZOO 101.hint: The first function is structural, the last is defensive.

ZOO 101.question: The sophisticated skeletal build-up of __________ allows it to stand erect.
ZOO 101.explanation: The sophisticated skeletal build-up of man allows it to stand erect.
ZOO 101.hint: Refers specifically to humans.

ZOO 101.question: The cuticle is composed of a protein called __________ and a thin waterproof layer of wax.
ZOO 101.explanation: The cuticle is composed of chitin and wax.
ZOO 101.hint: This is a key structural protein in arthropods.

ZOO 101.question: Because chitin is non-living, animals with this structure undergo moulting, also known as __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: Moulting is also known as ecdysis.
ZOO 101.hint: The biological term for the process of shedding the outer cuticle.

ZOO 101.question: The cuticle is an example of an __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The cuticle is an example of an exoskeleton.
ZOO 101.hint: It is an external supporting structure.

ZOO 101.question: Examples of organisms with a cuticle are Arthropods like insects, crabs, and __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: Scorpions are an example of an arthropod with a cuticle.
ZOO 101.hint: Another arthropod besides insects and crabs.

ZOO 101.question: Bones consist of living bone cells called __________ and protein fibres called collagen.
ZOO 101.explanation: The living bone cells are called osteocytes.
ZOO 101.hint: The mature cell type found within bone tissue.

ZOO 101.question: The minerals in bone are mainly __________ and calcium carbonate.
ZOO 101.explanation: Bone minerals are mainly calcium phosphate and calcium carbonate.
ZOO 101.hint: The primary salt providing rigidity is a phosphate.

ZOO 101.question: The hard outer layer of a bone is called the __________, and the cavity is filled with __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The hard outer layer is the shaft, and the cavity contains bone marrow.
ZOO 101.hint: The answer uses simple anatomical terms for the outer part and the inner content.

ZOO 101.question: Animals with bones include bony fish, toad, lizard, and __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: Mammals are animals with bones.
ZOO 101.hint: Think of a major vertebrate group with a bony endoskeleton.

ZOO 101.question: Cartilage consists of living cells called __________, carbohydrate, and protein fibre.
ZOO 101.explanation: The living cells in cartilage are called chondroblasts.
ZOO 101.hint: The cell name shares its root with the tissue name.

ZOO 101.question: Cartilage is found in the skeleton of complex __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: Cartilage is found in the skeletons of complex vertebrates.
ZOO 101.hint: Refers to animals with backbones.

ZOO 101.question: Examples of organisms with cartilage are cartilaginous fishes like __________ and rays.
ZOO 101.explanation: Sharks are an example of a cartilaginous fish.
ZOO 101.hint: A well-known fish whose skeleton is made of cartilage, not bone.

ZOO 101.question: The cartilage found in the trachea and on the surface of moveable joints is __________ cartilage.
ZOO 101.explanation: Hyaline cartilage is found in the trachea and on joint surfaces.
ZOO 101.hint: This is the most common and glassy-looking type of cartilage.

ZOO 101.question: Fibro-cartilage is found between the __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: Fibro-cartilage is found between the vertebrae in the intervertebral discs.
ZOO 101.hint: It acts as a shock absorber in the spinal column.

ZOO 101.question: Elastic cartilage is found in the ear and __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: Elastic cartilage is found in the ear and the epiglottis.
ZOO 101.hint: Think of a flexible structure in the throat that needs to spring back into place.

ZOO 101.question: A __________ skeleton is possessed by soft-bodied animals like the earthworm.
ZOO 101.explanation: A hydrostatic (or fluid) skeleton is possessed by animals like the earthworm.
ZOO 101.hint: This skeleton type uses fluid pressure for support and movement.

ZOO 101.question: An exoskeleton is found on the __________ part of the body.
ZOO 101.explanation: An exoskeleton is found on the external part of the body.
ZOO 101.hint: The prefix 'exo-' means outside.

ZOO 101.question: The exoskeleton of most invertebrates is composed of __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The exoskeleton of most invertebrates is composed of chitin.
ZOO 101.hint: This is the same material mentioned in the cuticle of arthropods.

ZOO 101.question: An endoskeleton is found __________ the body of the animal.
ZOO 101.explanation: An endoskeleton is found inside the body.
ZOO 101.hint: The prefix 'endo-' means within.

ZOO 101.question: The endoskeleton in mammals includes the skull, vertebral column, ribs, and the bones of the __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The mammalian endoskeleton includes the bones of the fore and hind limbs.
ZOO 101.hint: These are the appendages.

ZOO 101.question: The mammalian skeletal system is grouped into two major parts: the axial skeleton and the __________ skeleton.
ZOO 101.explanation: The two major parts are the axial and appendicular skeletons.
ZOO 101.hint: This part pertains to the limbs and their girdles.

ZOO 101.question: The axial skeleton comprises the skull, vertebral column, ribs, and __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The axial skeleton comprises the skull, vertebral column, ribs, and sternum.
ZOO 101.hint: This is the breastbone in the center of the chest.

ZOO 101.question: The appendicular skeleton is made up of the limb girdles and the __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The appendicular skeleton is made up of the limb girdles and the limbs.
ZOO 101.hint: This includes the arms and legs.

ZOO 101.question: The flat bones of the skull are joined by immovable joints called __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The immovable joints of the skull are called sutures.
ZOO 101.hint: These are the jagged, interlocking seams seen in a skull.

ZOO 101.question: The part of the skull that holds the brain is the __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The cranium is the part of the skull that holds the brain.
ZOO 101.hint: It is also called the brain box.

ZOO 101.question: The facial skeleton supports the nose, eyes, and muscles of the __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The facial skeleton supports the nose, eyes, and cheek muscles.
ZOO 101.hint: Think of the prominent area below the eyes.

ZOO 101.question: The upper jaw is called the __________ and the lower jaw is called the mandible.
ZOO 101.explanation: The upper jaw is called the maxilla.
ZOO 101.hint: This bone also holds the upper teeth.

ZOO 101.question: The skull protects the __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The skull protects the brain.
ZOO 101.hint: This is its primary protective function.

ZOO 101.question: The skull bears the __________ which help in grinding food.
ZOO 101.explanation: The skull bears the teeth, which help in grinding food.
ZOO 101.hint: These are the hard structures embedded in the jaw bones.

ZOO 101.question: The vertebral column is the central __________ structure of the skeleton.
ZOO 101.explanation: The vertebral column is the central supporting structure.
ZOO 101.hint: It is the main pillar that supports the body's weight.

ZOO 101.question: In humans, the vertebral column consists of __________ vertebrae.
ZOO 101.explanation: In humans, the vertebral column consists of 33 vertebrae.
ZOO 101.hint: This is the typical number before some fuse in adulthood.

ZOO 101.question: Between consecutive vertebrae are pads called __________ discs.
ZOO 101.explanation: The pads between vertebrae are called intervertebral discs.
ZOO 101.hint: The name describes their location 'between vertebrae'.

ZOO 101.question: The vertebrae are held together by strong __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The vertebrae are held together by strong ligaments.
ZOO 101.hint: These are fibrous connective tissues that connect bone to bone.

ZOO 101.question: In humans, rabbits, and rats, the number of cervical vertebrae is always __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The number of cervical vertebrae is always 7 in humans, rabbits, and rats.
ZOO 101.hint: Almost all mammals have this same number, regardless of neck length.

ZOO 101.question: Thoracic vertebrae are found in the __________ region.
ZOO 101.explanation: Thoracic vertebrae are found in the chest (thoracic) region.
ZOO 101.hint: These are the vertebrae that articulate with the ribs.

ZOO 101.question: Lumbar vertebrae are found in the __________ region.
ZOO 101.explanation: Lumbar vertebrae are found in the upper abdominal (lower back) region.
ZOO 101.hint: This is the region of the lower back, below the ribs.

ZOO 101.question: In humans, the sacral vertebrae are fused together to form the __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The fused sacral vertebrae form the sacrum.
ZOO 101.hint: It is a large, triangular bone at the base of the spine.

ZOO 101.question: Caudal vertebrae are found in the __________ region.
ZOO 101.explanation: Caudal vertebrae are found in the tail region.
ZOO 101.hint: 'Caudal' relates to the tail.

ZOO 101.question: The passage for the spinal cord is the __________ canal.
ZOO 101.explanation: The passage for the spinal cord is the neural canal.
ZOO 101.hint: It is named for the neural (nervous) structure it protects.

ZOO 101.question: The __________ projects upward dorsally for muscle attachment.
ZOO 101.explanation: The neural spine projects upward dorsally for muscle attachment.
ZOO 101.hint: It is the prominent spike you can feel down the middle of your back.

ZOO 101.question: The transverse processes project from the __________ of the vertebra.
ZOO 101.explanation: The transverse processes project from the side of the vertebra.
ZOO 101.hint: 'Transverse' means extending across or from side to side.

ZOO 101.question: The solid piece of bone below the neural canal is the __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The solid piece of bone below the neural canal is the centrum.
ZOO 101.hint: This is the main weight-bearing part of the vertebra.

ZOO 101.question: A __________ is a small, smooth, flat area for contact with another bone.
ZOO 101.explanation: A facet is a small, smooth, flat area for contact with another bone.
ZOO 101.hint: Think of a small, polished surface for articulation.

ZOO 101.question: The articular surfaces for successive vertebrae are called __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The articular surfaces for successive vertebrae are called zygapophyses.
ZOO 101.hint: These are the specific processes that interlock with those of adjacent vertebrae.

ZOO 101.question: Pre-zygapophyses face inward and __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: Pre-zygapophyses face inward and upward.
ZOO 101.hint: Their direction helps prevent the vertebra from sliding forward.

ZOO 101.question: Post-zygapophyses face outward and __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: Post-zygapophyses face outward and downward.
ZOO 101.hint: They articulate with the upward-facing processes of the vertebra behind.

ZOO 101.question: The first cervical vertebra is called the __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The first cervical vertebra is called the atlas.
ZOO 101.hint: Named after the Titan who held up the heavens, as it holds up the skull.

ZOO 101.question: The second cervical vertebra is called the __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The second cervical vertebra is called the axis.
ZOO 101.hint: It provides the pivot upon which the atlas and skull rotate.

ZOO 101.question: The atlas fits into the __________ __________ of the skull.
ZOO 101.explanation: The atlas fits into the occipital condyles of the skull.
ZOO 101.hint: These are the two rounded knobs on the underside of the occipital bone.

ZOO 101.question: A characteristic of the atlas is that the __________ is absent.
ZOO 101.explanation: A characteristic of the atlas is that the centrum is absent.
ZOO 101.hint: Its body is fused to the axis, forming the dens.

ZOO 101.question: The atlas has a __________ canal for the passage of blood vessels.
ZOO 101.explanation: The atlas has a vertebrarterial canal for the passage of blood vessels.
ZOO 101.hint: This canal allows for the vertebral artery to pass through.

ZOO 101.question: The axis articulates with the atlas through the __________ process.
ZOO 101.explanation: The axis articulates with the atlas through the odontoid process (dens).
ZOO 101.hint: This tooth-like projection acts as a pivot.

ZOO 101.question: Thoracic vertebrae have demifacets for the attachment of __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: Thoracic vertebrae have demifacets for the attachment of ribs.
ZOO 101.hint: This is a key distinguishing feature of vertebrae in the chest region.

ZOO 101.question: The neural spine of a thoracic vertebra projects upward and __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The neural spine of a thoracic vertebra projects upward and backward.
ZOO 101.hint: They are long and slanted, often pointing downwards, which is described as 'backward'.

ZOO 101.question: Lumbar vertebrae have a large, flattened __________ process.
ZOO 101.explanation: Lumbar vertebrae have a large, flattened transverse process.
ZOO 101.hint: These are the wing-like projections on the sides.

ZOO 101.question: For abdominal muscle attachment, lumbar vertebrae have extra projections called anapophysis and __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The extra projections are called anapophysis and metapophysis.
ZOO 101.hint: One is 'ana-', the other is 'meta-'.

ZOO 101.question: In humans, the five sacral vertebrae are fused to form the __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The fused sacral vertebrae form the sacrum.
ZOO 101.hint: This is a repeat from a previous question, confirming its importance.

ZOO 101.question: The sacrum is joined with the __________ girdle for support and strength.
ZOO 101.explanation: The sacrum is joined with the pelvic girdle.
ZOO 101.hint: This connection forms the posterior wall of the pelvic cavity.

ZOO 101.question: In humans, there are __________ pairs of ribs.
ZOO 101.explanation: In humans, there are 12 pairs of ribs.
ZOO 101.hint: A typical human has this number.

ZOO 101.question: The __________ is a single bone in the center of the chest.
ZOO 101.explanation: The sternum is the single bone in the center of the chest.
ZOO 101.hint: Also known as the breastbone.

ZOO 101.question: The ribs that are not attached to the sternum are called __________ ribs.
ZOO 101.explanation: Ribs not attached to the sternum are called floating ribs.
ZOO 101.hint: They 'float' because their ventral ends are free.

ZOO 101.question: The pectoral girdle holds the __________ limbs to the axial skeleton.
ZOO 101.explanation: The pectoral girdle holds the upper (or fore) limbs.
ZOO 101.hint: It is the shoulder girdle.

ZOO 101.question: The two large, flat, triangular bones of the pectoral girdle are called the __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The large, flat triangular bones are the scapulae (shoulder blades).
ZOO 101.hint: These are the bones you feel on your upper back.

ZOO 101.question: The two small, slender bones at the front of the pectoral girdle are the __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The small, slender bones at the front are the clavicles (collar bones).
ZOO 101.hint: These are the bones that run from the sternum to the shoulder.

ZOO 101.question: The depression on the scapula where the humerus fits is the __________ cavity.
ZOO 101.explanation: The depression on the scapula is the glenoid cavity (or fossa).
ZOO 101.hint: It is the socket for the ball of the humerus.

ZOO 101.question: The pelvic girdle consists of two halves joined at the __________ symphysis.
ZOO 101.explanation: The two halves of the pelvic girdle are joined at the pubis symphysis.
ZOO 101.hint: This is the fibrocartilage joint at the front of the pelvis.

ZOO 101.question: Each half of the pelvic girdle is made of three bones: the ilium, ischium, and __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The three bones are the ilium, ischium, and pubis.
ZOO 101.hint: These three bones fuse in adults to form one hip bone.

ZOO 101.question: The __________ is the largest and longest of the three pelvic bones.
ZOO 101.explanation: The ilium is the largest and longest of the three pelvic bones.
ZOO 101.hint: This is the flared, upper part of the hip bone.

ZOO 101.question: The cavity where the femur fits is called the __________ cavity.
ZOO 101.explanation: The cavity where the femur fits is the acetabulum.
ZOO 101.hint: This is the deep socket of the hip joint.

ZOO 101.question: The hole enclosed by the ischium and pubis is the __________ foramen.
ZOO 101.explanation: The hole enclosed by the ischium and pubis is the obturator foramen.
ZOO 101.hint: It is a large opening covered by a membrane.

ZOO 101.question: The basic plan for vertebrate limbs is the __________ limb plan.
ZOO 101.explanation: The basic plan is the pentadactyl (or 5-digit) limb plan.
ZOO 101.hint: The prefix 'penta-' means five.

ZOO 101.question: The upper arm bone is called the __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The upper arm bone is the humerus.
ZOO 101.hint: It is the bone of the brachium (upper arm).

ZOO 101.question: The bones of the wrist are called __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The bones of the wrist are called carpals.
ZOO 101.hint: Think of 'carpal tunnel syndrome'.

ZOO 101.question: The bones of the digits are called metacarpals and __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The bones of the digits (fingers/toes) are metacarpals/metatarsals and phalanges.
ZOO 101.hint: These are the bones of the individual fingers.

ZOO 101.question: The thigh bone is called the __________, which is the strongest bone in the body.
ZOO 101.explanation: The thigh bone is the femur.
ZOO 101.hint: It is the longest and strongest bone.

ZOO 101.question: The projections near the top of the femur for muscle attachment are called __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The projections near the top of the femur are called trochanters.
ZOO 101.hint: The greater and lesser trochanters are major sites for hip muscle attachment.

ZOO 101.question: The two rounded knobs at the distal end of the femur are called __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The rounded knobs at the distal end are the condyles.
ZOO 101.hint: They articulate with the tibia to form the knee joint.

ZOO 101.question: The shank is made up of the tibia and __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The shank (lower leg) is made up of the tibia and fibula.
ZOO 101.hint: The smaller, lateral bone of the lower leg.

ZOO 101.question: The knee cap is called the __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The knee cap is the patella.
ZOO 101.hint: It is a sesamoid bone embedded in the quadriceps tendon.

ZOO 101.question: The tarsals of the ankle form the __________ bone.
ZOO 101.explanation: The tarsals form the heel bone (specifically the calcaneus).
ZOO 101.hint: This is the bone that forms the prominence of the heel.

ZOO 101.question: A joint is a place where two or more bones __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: A joint is where two or more bones meet (or articulate).
ZOO 101.hint: The primary definition of a joint is a point of connection.

ZOO 101.question: Immovable joints in the skull are called __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The immovable joints of the skull are sutures.
ZOO 101.hint: This repeats an earlier point, confirming its importance.

ZOO 101.question: A __________ joint, like in the shoulder, allows movement in all directions (360Â°).
ZOO 101.explanation: A ball and socket joint allows movement in all directions.
ZOO 101.hint: Named for the ball-like end of one bone fitting into a socket of another.

ZOO 101.question: A __________ joint, like in the elbow, allows movement in only one direction.
ZOO 101.explanation: A hinge joint allows movement in only one plane (like a door hinge).
ZOO 101.hint: The elbow and knee are classic examples.

ZOO 101.question: Wrist and ankle joints are examples of __________ joints.
ZOO 101.explanation: Wrist and ankle joints are examples of gliding (or sliding) joints.
ZOO 101.hint: These joints allow limited sliding movements between flat bone surfaces.

ZOO 101.question: The joint between the atlas and axis is a __________ joint, allowing rotation.
ZOO 101.explanation: The joint between the atlas and axis is a pivot joint.
ZOO 101.hint: This joint allows the head to rotate side-to-side, as in saying 'no'.

ZOO 101.question: Ligaments hold __________ together at a joint.
ZOO 101.explanation: Ligaments hold bones together at a joint.
ZOO 101.hint: They are connective tissues that connect bone to bone.

ZOO 101.question: Tendons join __________ to bones.
ZOO 101.explanation: Tendons join muscles to bones.
ZOO 101.hint: They are the tough, fibrous ends of muscles.

ZOO 101.question: __________ cartilage protects bones from wear and tear at joints.
ZOO 101.explanation: Articular cartilage protects bones from wear and tear at joints.
ZOO 101.hint: It is the smooth, white tissue that covers the ends of bones where they meet.

ZOO 101.question: The synovial membrane secretes __________ fluid.
ZOO 101.explanation: The synovial membrane secretes synovial fluid.
ZOO 101.hint: The fluid is named after the membrane that secretes it.

ZOO 101.question: Synovial fluid reduces __________ between bones.
ZOO 101.explanation: Synovial fluid reduces friction between bones.
ZOO 101.hint: It acts as a lubricant for the joint.

ZOO 101.question: The space containing the synovial fluid is the synovial __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: The space is the synovial capsule (or cavity).
ZOO 101.hint: It is the enclosed space within the joint capsule.

ZOO 101.question: Muscles are joined to bone by __________.
ZOO 101.explanation: Muscles are joined to bone by tendons.
ZOO 101.hint: This repeats a key point from the joint structure section.

ZOO 101.question: An __________ pair of muscles work against each other.
ZOO 101.explanation: An antagonist pair of muscles work against each other.
ZOO 101.hint: For example, the biceps and triceps are antagonists.

ZOO 101.question: The biceps muscle __________ the arm.
ZOO 101.explanation: The biceps muscle bends (or flexes) the arm.
ZOO 101.hint: It is the primary flexor of the elbow.

ZOO 101.question: The triceps muscle is an example of an __________ muscle that straightens the arm.
ZOO 101.explanation: The triceps is an extensor muscle that straightens the arm.
ZOO 101.hint: It opposes the action of the biceps.
